description: From Middle English hoten, hoaten, haten, from Old English hātan (“to command, be called”), from Proto-West Germanic *haitan, from Proto-Germanic *haitaną (“command, name”), from Proto-Indo-European *keyd-, from *key- (“put in motion, be moving”).

verbs.description: hote (third-person singular simple present hotes, present participle hoting, simple past hight, past participle hoten)

entries.meaning: (transitive, dialectal or obsolete) To command; to enjoin.
examples: The captain hight five sailors stay on the other side of the inlet and guard the cargo.
Beowulf hight his men build a great mead-hall, the kind of which man's progeny should hear tell forever.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To be called, be named.
